headline: Walt Disney Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the first quarter 2011 Walt Disney Earnings Conference Call. My name is Kendall, and I will be your coordinator for today. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the conference over to your host for
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the first quarter 2011 Walt Disney Earnings Conference Call. My name is Kendall, and I will be your coordinator for today. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the conference over to your host for today, Mr. Lowell Singer, Senior Vice President of Investor Relations. Please proceed.

headline: Walt Disney Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Kendall. Good afternoon, everyone, and welcome to Walt Disney Company's First Quarter 2011 Earnings Call. A press release was issued almost an our ago and its available on our website at www.disney.com/investors. Today's call is also being webcast
componenttext:
Thanks, Kendall. Good afternoon, everyone, and welcome to Walt Disney Company's First Quarter 2011 Earnings Call. A press release was issued almost an our ago and its available on our website at www.disney.com/investors. Today's call is also being webcast, and the webcast will also be available on our website. After the call, a replay and transcript will be there as well. 
Joining me from Burbank today are Bob Iger, Disney's President and Chief Executive Officer; and Jay Rasulo, Senior Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. Bob's going to lead off, followed by Jay, and then we will of course be happy to take some of your questions. 
So with that, let me turn the call over to Bob we'll get started.

headline: Walt Disney Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Lowell, and good afternoon. I'm pleased to report we had an excellent first quarter, driven by strong creative content and our unique ability to leverage great entertainment across the many businesses and markets in which we operate. We also be
componenttext:
Thank you, Lowell, and good afternoon. I'm pleased to report we had an excellent first quarter, driven by strong creative content and our unique ability to leverage great entertainment across the many businesses and markets in which we operate. We also benefited from growth in advertising at our Media Networks and improved consumer spending in our Parks and Consumer Products businesses. Net income was up 54% to $1.3 billion on a 10% revenue increase. EPS for the quarter, adjusting for comparability, grew 45% to $0.68.
Next week we're holding an investor conference so today I'm going to keep my remarks brief. Our performance again shows the value of our relentless focus on three core strategic priorities: Creating great entertainment, using new technology to enhance the quality and reach of that entertainment and growing our businesses and promising international markets. Nothing epitomizes our commitment to quality, creativity and future growth like the recently christened Disney cruise ship, the Disney Dream. The Dream demonstrates how we successfully built our legacy of great storytelling, technological innovation and first rate service to create a truly amazing guest experience as only we can. The impact on bookings for the entire fleet has been tremendous. 
Animation has always been at the heart of Disney, and this quarter showed how incredibly beneficial strong animated films can be for the company. Tangled, the crowd-pleasing fairytale adventure, is close to $500 million in global box office, with Japan yet to open. And has added Rapunzel to our popular court of Disney Princesses. Toy Story 3, already the number one animated movie of all time at the box office, did very well in its home video release, was a key part of the holiday success of our Consumer Products business, and I'm happy to say has been nominated for five Oscars, including Best Picture.
We also are extremely pleased with the performance of our Parks and Resorts. Despite difficult weather conditions in the U.S. and Europe, we enjoyed increases in attendance at spending at our U.S. parks with new attractions coming online, at our parks, our new Hawaiian resort opening in August and the expanded Disney Cruise Line, there will be multiple additional reasons for families to enjoy great Disney vacation. 
Our Media Networks, led by ESPN, once again had a very solid quarter. The Bowl Championship Series on ESPN was a big success in its first year, with the Auburn Oregon final being the most watched telecast in cable television history. Monday Night Football had its highest rated and most viewed season since 2006 when it moved from ABC to ESPN. Disney Channel, with its expanded portfolio of original programming, had its best ever first quarter in terms of total viewership. In ABC and particularly its own stations benefited substantially from the continued improvement in advertising rates. 
In sum, we are very pleased with how we've started off the new fiscal year. We've got a strong created strategy focused on building our brands and franchises, a talented team and a consistent focus on growing our businesses in rapidly changing markets.
And with that, I'll turn things over to Jay.

headline: Walt Disney Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bob, and good afternoon, everyone. We delivered strong results in our first quarter, with double-digit growth in overall operating income and margin improvement across all of our businesses. Before we turn to your questions, I'd like to highligh
componenttext:
Thanks, Bob, and good afternoon, everyone. We delivered strong results in our first quarter, with double-digit growth in overall operating income and margin improvement across all of our businesses. 
Before we turn to your questions, I'd like to highlight the key drivers of our Q1 performance and discuss some of the trends and comparison issues that will influence our results for Q2 and the remainder of the year.
Profits at the Media Networks were up 47%, led by strong growth in advertising and affiliate revenue at cable networks. Ad revenue for ESPN came in 34% above prior year, driven in part by strong demand for NFL programming at the back of another year of extremely strong NFL ratings. In the quarter, ESPN added two BCS games, the Rose and Fiesta bowls. After adjusting for these two BCS games, we estimate that ESPN's ad revenue was up 27%. Thus far in Q2, ESPN ad sales are pacing up double digits versus prior year. 
Affiliate and advertising revenue in Q1 were also up at Disney Channel worldwide. In addition, results benefited from higher equity income from ANE Lifetime driven by improved performance. 
At broadcasting, results benefited from higher advertising at our own TV stations, cost reduction in use and daytime production and the shift of the Rose Bowl to ESPN. Ad revenue at our TV stations was up 20% from prior Q1, driven by higher political advertising demand. So far in Q2, ad sales pacings at the TV stations are up double digits versus prior year.
At the Networks, ABC pricing at Q1 came in 24% above upfront levels. So far this quarter, scatter pricing for ABC is running over 30% above at front levels. 
At Studio Entertainment, operating income improved significantly year-over-year, driven by reduced home entertainment distribution and marketing costs. In addition, increased home video units were driven by Toy Story 3's strong Home Entertainment performance and its earlier international release dates compared to last year's release of Up. Results were also helped by lower film write-downs.
Our Parks segment delivered strong double-digit operating income growth, driven primarily by higher guest spending, as well as increased room nights and attendance. Margins grew by 220 basis points, despite increased expenses from labor cost inflation and higher pension and healthcare costs, as well as expenses associated with our newly launched ship, the Disney Dream, and our Disney California Adventure expansion. Domestic attendance came in 2% above prior year levels. Higher admission pricing in part due to a reduction in discounting and higher food and beverage spending helped drive an 8% increase in per capita guest spending. Occupancy across our domestic hotels came in four percentage points above prior year levels at 85%. Average room spending was up 4%. Results also improved at our international parks, with higher guest spending and room nights in Paris and Hong Kong.  Looking ahead, domestic room reservations for Q2 are currently running 3% above prior year levels. 
At Consumer Products we enjoyed continued strength in our Licensing business, primarily driven by Toy Story merchandise. On a comparable basis, earned licensing revenue was up 12% year-over-year. Higher results also reflected the inclusion of Marvel licensing and publishing business, and improved performance at our Disney Stores North America.
Operating performance in the Interactive Media segment was in line with prior year. Solid results from our self-published games, particularly Epic Mickey and Toy Story 3, were offset by the consolidation of Playdom. Playdom's results were largely driven by purchase accounting, which will continue to impact results for the remainder of the year. 
We continue to be very pleased with advertising and park trends and remain excited about our product lineup for the remainder of the year. Separate from these trends, however, there are a few comparability issues I want to bring to your attention that will impact our Q2 report results. At Media Networks, ESPN's results will be impacted by the cost of adding three BCS games, as well as airing the Cricket World Cup by our ESPN Star Sports joint venture. Studio Entertainment faces tough comps given last year's release of Alice in Wonderland in Q2, as we have no comparable release planned this quarter. In addition Home Video comparisons will be difficult given that Up was released in many international markets in Q2 of last year. 
I also want to remind you that the timing of the Easter holiday will impact our Parks and Resort results, falling entirely in Q3 this year versus last year when one week of the holiday period fell into Q2. Our Q2 results will also include costs associated with the January launch of our new cruise ship, the Disney Dream.
During Q1, we continued to repurchase shares. For the fiscal year so far, we've purchased over 28 million shares for approximately $1 billion. Our 2011 is off to a very good start, and we look forward to discussing our strategy and initiatives in more detail with you next week at our Investor Conference.
With that, I'll turn the call back to Lowell for Q&A.

headline: Walt Disney Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jay. As everyone knows, we will be hosting an Investor Conference next week, and that investor conference will be webcast. At the conference, management will address a variety of key strategic issues. As such, to the extent possible, we'd like to
componenttext:
Thanks, Jay. As everyone knows, we will be hosting an Investor Conference next week, and that investor conference will be webcast. At the conference, management will address a variety of key strategic issues. As such, to the extent possible, we'd like to use today's call to address your questions about our Q1 results and current trends since we don't plan to focus on those topics next week. We are certainly allocating time during next week's conference to answer your broader strategic questions. 
So with that preference, operator, we're ready to take the first question.

headline: Walt Disney Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2011
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Ben Swinburne with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Ben Swinburne with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Walt Disney Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2011
componenttextpreview: Jay, just want to go back on your comments on ESPN advertising, I think last quarter, you said that ESPN was pacing double-digits and you put up a plus 34 or plus 27 adjustments so just trying to see if you could build more with double-digit pacing in the
componenttext: Jay, just want to go back on your comments on ESPN advertising, I think last quarter, you said that ESPN was pacing double-digits and you put up a plus 34 or plus 27 adjustments so just trying to see if you could build more with double-digit pacing in the Q2 comment that you made. And then on the Studio, I'm sure you benefited for some licensing film share in the quarter, given how strong your product line has been. But you spent the last two years right-sizing the cost structure there. So any help you could give us on how much cost that sort of annualized in terms of overhead savings are taking out of the Studio over the last two years so we could think about the underlying profitability would be helpful.

headline: Walt Disney Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2011
componenttextpreview: Let me take your first question about advertising. I don't want to be more explicit than up double digits for ESPN. We really are not in the habit of giving explicit guidance, and I think we'll leave it at that. Relative to the Studio returns, there clear
componenttext: Let me take your first question about advertising. I don't want to be more explicit than up double digits for ESPN. We really are not in the habit of giving explicit guidance, and I think we'll leave it at that. Relative to the Studio returns, there clearly were particularly in our distribution, Bob and I have talked a lot about how we have reoriented our distribution organization and our marketing organizations to really span all of the channels in the film's release. And part of the benefit of that has been felt in the Home Entertainment segment where we really have reduced both the marketing and distribution costs of taking our product to market. So the savings that are there in the improvement were not solely related to film share by any stretch of the imagination. What that annualizes out at is I'm not going to get into there are a different numbers of the releases and different products in the market every year and how we market them. I don't want to make a commitment about how that cost is going to annualize.

headline: Walt Disney Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2011
componenttextpreview: This is Bob. I'll add one thing about ESPN and that is that while we're not going to give any more details about pacings from a percentage perspective, it's safe to assume that the sports advertising marketplace is extremely robust as is by the way the ov
componenttext: This is Bob. I'll add one thing about ESPN and that is that while we're not going to give any more details about pacings from a percentage perspective, it's safe to assume that the sports advertising marketplace is extremely robust as is by the way the overall marketplace. ESPN seeing strength from multiple sectors, there certainly is real strength in automotives, in retail, in telcos, in various forms of consumer electronics, even to the point where they have been able to add units in this quarter to take advantage of demand. In programs like SportsCenter and PTI. So they're seeing a very, very strong marketplace.

headline: Walt Disney Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Spencer Wang with Credit Suisse.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Spencer Wang with Credit Suisse.

headline: Walt Disney Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2011
componenttextpreview: For Jay or Bob, in the event that there is a work stopped in for either of the NFL or the NBA, can you just walk us through how that would impact expenses recognized and would there be an impact on affiliate revenues given the programming covenants. And t
componenttext: For Jay or Bob, in the event that there is a work stopped in for either of the NFL or the NBA, can you just walk us through how that would impact expenses recognized and would there be an impact on affiliate revenues given the programming covenants. And then one housekeeping question for the quarter for Jay, I guess, if you x out the New York shift in the year-ago quarter how would attendance been up year-over-year?

headline: Walt Disney Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2011
componenttextpreview: We have provisions in our NBA and NFL contracts that deal with potential for loss of games for a variety of different reasons, including work stoppage over labor disagreement. But we do not make any details of those provisions public, which is our obligat
componenttext: We have provisions in our NBA and NFL contracts that deal with potential for loss of games for a variety of different reasons, including work stoppage over labor disagreement. But we do not make any details of those provisions public, which is our obligation to the league, just as we don't make much of the details with these contracts public. I think that you're pretty familiar with the program covenant that we have, where the cable operators, where we don't recognize revenue until we achieve a certain level in terms of live programming. We don't make the details of that available either in terms of the number of live programming or the components we have to deliver. So I think it would be best right now just to not provide any more detail than that.

headline: Walt Disney Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2011
componenttextpreview: On your question on Q1 attendance there, there wasn't any new year's impact between the two years.
componenttext: On your question on Q1 attendance there, there wasn't any new year's impact between the two years.

headline: Walt Disney Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Jessica Reif-Cohen with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jessica Reif-Cohen with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Walt Disney Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2011
componenttextpreview: Could you tell us what retransmission consent is up to now, and if you could include reverse comp that would be great. And how much further improvement can you make in fiscal '11 and fiscal '12 and I wanted to talk Jay said the opening of the Dream drove
componenttext: Could you tell us what retransmission consent is up to now, and if you could include reverse comp that would be great. And how much further improvement can you make in fiscal '11 and fiscal '12 and I wanted to talk Jay said the opening of the Dream drove cruise bookings. Can you give us any color on what the impact was on overall bookings? Obviously there's more inventory and it was a bigger ship with higher prices. And Bob, you mentioned in the shareholder letter this year, you actually discussed the Shanghai park and I was wondering if the deal has actually been finalized.

headline: Walt Disney Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2011
componenttextpreview: Retransmission consent, we've caught some deals and reversed compensation. We've cut some deals already Time Warner being I guess the most obvious. There will be more deals to come. We fully expect to gain retransmission consent payments from distributors
componenttext: Retransmission consent, we've caught some deals and reversed compensation. We've cut some deals already Time Warner being I guess the most obvious. There will be more deals to come. We fully expect to gain retransmission consent payments from distributors as deals that are currently in place expire. And we can't give you a sense for when those are, but there are negotiations going on just about all the time, nor can you tell you the percentage of deals that we've already completed or the amount of revenue that we're bringing in. We may give you some ranges about once all these deals are done, what it might mean in terms of steady-state revenue improvement, but we'll discuss that next week at the Investor Conference. The second question about the Dream, Jay I think mentioned in his opening comments that bookings for all three ships were quite strong. They are running over 80% for the year. The Dream itself is 89% booked for the year. So there's considerable interest in our Cruise business. We believe that the fact that the Dream is so booked, particularly during peak periods has actually driven people whose interest was sparked in part by the addition of the new ship to our other ships at our other itineraries. It's been very positive for us. And we've also been selling basically new cruises to people who have been on the Dream. So we've seen some encouraging reaction to people who are already sailing on the Dream and want to come back. On Shanghai, we've signed multiple agreements with the Shanghai government and our prospective partners for Shanghai Disneyland. We had received, prior to signing those agreements, preliminary approval from the Beijing or the central government, and we're now awaiting a final or formal approval from the Beijing government before we make a formal announcement and actually break ground. And we're not going to speculate when that will be.

headline: Walt Disney Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Doug Mitchelson with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Doug Mitchelson with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Walt Disney Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2011
componenttextpreview: If you look at fiscal '01 to fiscal '02, Parks drop in EBIT about $600 million or so about four years after to get back to the prior profit level. Fiscal '08 to fiscal '10 again dropped almost $600 million in EBIT, but you did improve $6 million domestica
componenttext: If you look at fiscal '01 to fiscal '02, Parks drop in EBIT about $600 million or so about four years after to get back to the prior profit level. Fiscal '08 to fiscal '10 again dropped almost $600 million in EBIT, but you did improve $6 million domestically in one quarter. So the question is it looks like your more on pace to recover in two years, and it looks like you're in an inflection point in the Parks in the recovery and one is that accurate, do you sort of feel that momentum? And two, if so, if it looks like it could recover faster than last time is there anything you can point to any particular factors that is driving that?

headline: Walt Disney Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2011
componenttextpreview: I would say this. I think it's clear that we have what we've been saying for the last couple of quarters, about implementing a strategy to bring us back to our normalized pricing at, as we're waiting for demand to come back it has clearly manifested itsel
componenttext: I would say this. I think it's clear that we have what we've been saying for the last couple of quarters, about implementing a strategy to bring us back to our normalized pricing at, as we're waiting for demand to come back it has clearly manifested itself again in this quarter as we discussed last quarter. And so, we're certainly on a trajectory that we expected to be on and talked about. I don't want to be explicit about the timing, but I will tell you that from our perspective, the combination of continuing to add great product to our parks around the world, as well as the interest in travel definitely coming back and the sense that we have incredible value in the way we priced our products is manifesting itself in a lot of interest. Bob mentioned what's going on in our Cruise business, just blowing the doors off in terms of demand and interest. And we're seeing that in the volume as we gave out the numbers in both our domestic parks, as well as in Hong Kong and in Paris. So it's very broad-based, but the speed and rate of trajectory, I don't want to take a guess about that.

headline: Walt Disney Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2011
componenttextpreview: We're still seeing, Doug, a consumer that's shopping for value, and it's still shopping late. There is a significant change in booking window for instance. So you still have an environment that while less challenged than it was certainly a year ago, it st
componenttext: We're still seeing, Doug, a consumer that's shopping for value, and it's still shopping late. There is a significant change in booking window for instance. So you still have an environment that while less challenged than it was certainly a year ago, it still has its challenges. And  one thing that I think is interesting and we pointed this out before if you look back at the early part of the last decade, where we obviously experienced some difficult recession and other significant events like 9/11 and Middle East war, we're much better positioned today than we were then in terms of the mix of value-priced rooms, where back then we had a larger percentage of premium priced rooms and now, we've built and we continue to build. In fact, we are building right now a new value priced resort in Orlando. And so we're more accessible and we're more accessibly priced then we were then, and it doesn't have to do with discounting. It just has to do with the inventory that we currently are making available. I think that's a positive thing.

headline: Walt Disney Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Nathanson with Nomura.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Nathanson with Nomura.

headline: Walt Disney Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2011
componenttextpreview: On Marvel, Jay, it looks like I think the Licensing group grew about 9% this quarter and I'm wondering is there anything unusual in this quarter that will peak for the year? Is there anything one-time on growth this quarter?
componenttext: On Marvel, Jay, it looks like I think the Licensing group grew about 9% this quarter and I'm wondering is there anything unusual in this quarter that will peak for the year? Is there anything one-time on growth this quarter?

headline: Walt Disney Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of things. I wouldn't call it anything unusual, but remember that we are now operating under the Time Warner agreement and subs have resumed their growth. And that has contributed to increased affiliate fees. I wouldn't call this unusual, bu
componenttext: Just a couple of things. I wouldn't call it anything unusual, but remember that we are now operating under the Time Warner agreement and subs have resumed their growth. And that has contributed to increased affiliate fees. I wouldn't call this unusual, but they're definitely contributing factors.

headline: Walt Disney Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2011
componenttextpreview: Bob, when you bought Marvel, one thing you talked about was taking control of the international licensing of Marvel, and now you had it for a good part of the year. Whether if you could talk to us what you see in the licensing side from Marvel directly un
componenttext: Bob, when you bought Marvel, one thing you talked about was taking control of the international licensing of Marvel, and now you had it for a good part of the year. Whether if you could talk to us what you see in the licensing side from Marvel directly under Disney's leadership?

headline: Walt Disney Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well we're pleased with the integration that we've done internationally, moving out basically third-party agents and replacing them with Disney licensing people. We've been working really hard with Marvel to basically get up to speed with all the Marvel p
componenttext: Well we're pleased with the integration that we've done internationally, moving out basically third-party agents and replacing them with Disney licensing people. We've been working really hard with Marvel to basically get up to speed with all the Marvel properties. And their general approach to licensing in the marketplace. We had in the market last year as a new product, Iron Man and from a licensing perspective, that was slightly less than we would've liked to have been. Still a very strong product coming into the market for '11 is Thor and Captain America, and then of course in 2012, Avengers, which features as we all know Captain America, and Hawk, Thor and Iron Man. And we're very, very excited about that as a potential franchise for the company. So a lot of the work that we've been doing is essentially managing what I'll call day-to-day under now one company roof, and preparing ourselves for what we believe are great prospects for franchises in the future, notably Avengers, and then hopefully ultimately Iron Man after that. We feel good about their product pipeline, and we feel good about the work we've been doing to learn more about Marvel and the overall licensing opportunities, and obviously, to put the organizations together.

headline: Walt Disney Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Richard Greenfield with BTIG.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Richard Greenfield with BTIG.

headline: Walt Disney Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2011
componenttextpreview: On theme parks, Bob, I think you started out by mentioning that weather both domestically and internationally played a factor in the quarter, and yet you were still up in attendance. I'm curious any way to think about the impact on revenues for profit tha
componenttext: On theme parks, Bob, I think you started out by mentioning that weather both domestically and internationally played a factor in the quarter, and yet you were still up in attendance. I'm curious any way to think about the impact on revenues for profit that you think you lost or impacted by people who couldn't make it et cetera. And two, I think Tom Sands was quoted in the last week answering a question related to the impact of Potter Land universal basically saying it safe to say it didn't help us, but it didn't really hurt us and we are just hoping to be can expand on how much of an impact you think Harry Potter has had on you and do you think as I starts to wear off, in terms of the newness of that park, would that actually benefit results going forward next few quarters?

headline: Walt Disney Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2011
componenttextpreview: We had a trifecta in terms of weather in December with an ice storm in Europe that basically brought Europe to a standstill. Now we had a week of torrential rains in California and we had a major Northeast blizzard right after Christmas that shut all the
componenttext: We had a trifecta in terms of weather in December with an ice storm in Europe that basically brought Europe to a standstill. Now we had a week of torrential rains in California and we had a major Northeast blizzard right after Christmas that shut all the airports down across the northeast and made it impossible to travel. We fully expect that there will be a lot of people from that area would be going down to Orlando for instance. But we cannot quantify exactly what it is that we lost from a revenue perspective. By the way in California, we may have made up for some of it once the rain stopped because you get a lot of local attendance particularly during the holiday season when kids are out of school but its just really difficult to quantify. I'll let Jay take a stab at Harry Potter Land. Except I will say they built a great property down there, not meant to be an advertisement for the competitor. And I believe that when a competitor puts a good property in the marketplace, it brings more people rather to the market. So I think it stimulates attendance to Orlando. And we all know that that's good for us because we usually get a good piece of all visitation to Orlando.

headline: Walt Disney Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2011
componenttextpreview: Right, just continuing on that, I mentioned that our domestic parks were up 2%, Orlando was actually up more than 2%. So the impact, if there is any, of what Bob is probably being swamped by what Bob described, that to the extent that it brings more peopl
componenttext: Right, just continuing on that, I mentioned that our domestic parks were up 2%, Orlando was actually up more than 2%. So the impact, if there is any, of what Bob is probably being swamped by what Bob described, that to the extent that it brings more people to the market, we do get a big share of that. On your other question related to weather impacts, I only give you this insight. Needless to say, local people are more affected in general by weather than long-distance people. And across the quarter, our attendance was down on the resident side, but very much up on the international and long distance tourist side. It gives directionally some sense that we were definitely hurt by within the quarter. Whether that's a lasting effect, it usually isn't.

headline: Walt Disney Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2011
componenttextpreview: Jay, you said Domestic was up 2% of the quarter and Orlando was up more than 2%. Was California actually up as well?
componenttext: Jay, you said Domestic was up 2% of the quarter and Orlando was up more than 2%. Was California actually up as well?

headline: Walt Disney Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2011
componenttextpreview: California Park was slightly down for the quarter.
componenttext: California Park was slightly down for the quarter.

headline: Walt Disney Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Anthony DiClemente with Barclays Capital.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Anthony DiClemente with Barclays Capital.

headline: Walt Disney Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2011
componenttextpreview: One on ESPN and one on the parks, just wondering at pricing in the scatter market I'm just wondering your ratings are way up and just trying to disaggregate pricing in units and wondering if you're seeing the premium versus upfront pricing widen as we mov
componenttext: One on ESPN and one on the parks, just wondering at pricing in the scatter market I'm just wondering your ratings are way up and just trying to disaggregate pricing in units and wondering if you're seeing the premium versus upfront pricing widen as we move forward in this time here. And I have a follow up.

headline: Walt Disney Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2011
componenttextpreview: Scatter pricing at the network is up about 30% over the upfront, and up double digits at ESPN. ESPN actually participates in a few different upfronts. So it's a slightly more difficult thing, except my comments earlier about ESPN's advertising marketplace
componenttext: Scatter pricing at the network is up about 30% over the upfront, and up double digits at ESPN. ESPN actually participates in a few different upfronts. So it's a slightly more difficult thing, except my comments earlier about ESPN's advertising marketplace obviously are relevant here. They're just having a gangbuster advertising revenue quarter right now, and we believe that's going to continue. Is there a second part of that question that I missed?

headline: Walt Disney Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2011
componenttextpreview: I have a different question on parks. Jay, I think you say that Q2 reservation at the parks are pacing up 3% as of now presumably that is inclusive of the difficult Easter comparison. So I'm just wondering if you can give us a more normalized estimate or
componenttext: I have a different question on parks. Jay, I think you say that Q2 reservation at the parks are pacing up 3% as of now presumably that is inclusive of the difficult Easter comparison. So I'm just wondering if you can give us a more normalized estimate or roughly what would that 3% equate to if it's possible if you could normalize the Easter comp.

headline: Walt Disney Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2011
componenttextpreview: There's not a big room night move on the Easter  comp in terms of occupancy. Basically, it's more on the rate and spending side. And the day visitor side, that affects the weeks of Easter in the quarter. The occupancy is not that different so I wouldn't m
componenttext: There's not a big room night move on the Easter  comp in terms of occupancy. Basically, it's more on the rate and spending side. And the day visitor side, that affects the weeks of Easter in the quarter. The occupancy is not that different so I wouldn't make a big adjustment for it.  The OI move I discussed, in previous quarters of the Easter ship is about $20 million round numbers.

headline: Walt Disney Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2011
componenttextpreview: Jay, on the balance sheet, projects in progress increased $800 million. Is that the cruise ship and other assets went down $700 million? Can you just give us an idea of what's happening there? And then in terms of the hotel bookings at the theme park, the
componenttext: Jay, on the balance sheet, projects in progress increased $800 million. Is that the cruise ship and other assets went down $700 million? Can you just give us an idea of what's happening there? And then in terms of the hotel bookings at the theme park, they were up 3% as Anthony said, it was up 5% in the net last conference call wondering what the difference is in the slowdown it sounds like the turns are excellent, so is it just the pricing is much higher than it was a quarter ago?

headline: Walt Disney Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2011
componenttextpreview: Pricing is -- let me answer your question, pricing is higher than it was a quarter ago. That bubble we doesn't account for the difference between the 5% and 3%. Remember, you're comparing quarter on quarter so we've been increasing our occupancy bookings
componenttext: Pricing is -- let me answer your question, pricing is higher than it was a quarter ago. That bubble we doesn't account for the difference between the 5% and 3%. Remember, you're comparing quarter on quarter so we've been increasing our occupancy bookings over the last four or five quarters. I wouldn't read a big difference between 3% and 5% at this point anyway. And on your first question, to be explicit, yes, it's the cruise ship and it's the Miramax sale.

headline: Walt Disney Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2011
componenttextpreview: Can you talk a little bit more about the consumer products revenue growth? Just looking at the Q, you had very good headline revenue growth in that provision, but a chunk came from the market acquisition?
componenttext: Can you talk a little bit more about the consumer products revenue growth? Just looking at the Q, you had very good headline revenue growth in that provision, but a chunk came from the market acquisition?

headline: Walt Disney Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, there was revenue due to the consolidation of the Marvel acquisition. But there was an offset in sort of core underlying consumer product performance because of the increase in film share that gets recognized at the studio. But the fundamental that c
componenttext: Yes, there was revenue due to the consolidation of the Marvel acquisition. But there was an offset in sort of core underlying consumer product performance because of the increase in film share that gets recognized at the studio. But the fundamental that consumer products were pretty much across-the-board. The licensing comparables were up, the Disney Store revenue has been up and then Marvel, both the Marvel licensing business and the publishing business being included in the results all accounted for the increase in overall CP. Needless to say, this is due to the strength of Toy Story 3 on the licensing side and largely on the Disney store side where the comparables on our renovated stores are quite strong compared to what they are prior to renovation.

headline: Walt Disney Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2011

headline: Walt Disney Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2011
componenttextpreview: I don't know if this sounds like a strategic question, Bob, but I wanted to get your take on as you think about all the explosion of applications and interconnected devices, it seems like basically it's a battle between Apple- and Android-enabled operatin
componenttext: I don't know if this sounds like a strategic question, Bob, but I wanted to get your take on as you think about all the explosion of applications and interconnected devices, it seems like basically it's a battle between Apple- and Android-enabled operating systems. So when you think about your strategy there and giving obviously crucial position that Steve Jobs holds in the company, is it fair to say at this point, that you're kind of more inclined to go with the IOS operating system in terms of kind of the device interoperability that you're talking about here, or are you more like experimenting with pretty much everyone out there in terms of an open kind of platform? Some color there would be helpful.

headline: Walt Disney Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2011
componenttextpreview: I'll just say yes. I am going to spend a fair amount of time next week talking about our digital media strategy overall, but I don't want to be dismissive of your question. There isn't one company, Apple or any other company for that matter, that's drivin
componenttext: I'll just say yes. I am going to spend a fair amount of time next week talking about our digital media strategy overall, but I don't want to be dismissive of your question. There isn't one company, Apple or any other company for that matter, that's driving our strategy. What's driving the strategy is really the incredible developments we're seeing on the technology side that when added to great content and brands provide for more opportunity than we've ever seen before. And more opportunity for the consumer as well, not just to consume more media, but to do it in more places and with more convenience in access and navigation and interoperability. The decisions we're making in terms of what media we'll distribute our product are made based on variety of things. We want to be in a good place on a good platform, where there is good navigation and decent access to revenue. And our brand and our products are in effect showcased well and its reliable for the consumer. We want to be in places that we have growth potential so that the underlying technology or the underlying capital behind the effort is such that the platform's going to be around for a long time. And we're looking, both domestically and internationally, for opportunities to essentially create more competition among distributors. When you have great content, the more out there in terms of the ability to distribute your content to consumer the better off you are. And then there's another factor or a couple of other factors that are important. One, piracy. There's no question that being available, well priced, well time to the market is one of the best ways to combat piracy, and we have got to continue to be mindful of that because the absence of being available in a world where there's great technology and great content can be very dangerous. And then I think it's also important for us to be relevant. When you're on these new platforms you just appear to be more relevant to the consumer, and I think that is both brand enhancing and business enhancing. So I don't know if I'm choosing iOS and Android and then getting all those details we might get a little more detail with you next week but I'd be glad to discuss and will discuss in much more detail our thoughts about what's going on in the marketplace in terms of digital media and changing consumer behavior and all the different opportunities that accompany like Disney, with brands, Disney/Pixar, Marvel, ESPN, ABC, all the opportunities that we're seeing. It's pretty interesting time. And it's important to be out in front and to be experimental because we haven't discovered yet the silver bullet or the business model that's going to prevail. Probably will be many.

headline: Walt Disney Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2011
componenttextpreview: So you rolled out authenticated ESPN, which seems like a groundbreaking milestone for you. And when you think about Disney Channel, for example, and is that something that could also be on the table for authentication, or is that pretty much hampered by t
componenttext: So you rolled out authenticated ESPN, which seems like a groundbreaking milestone for you. And when you think about Disney Channel, for example, and is that something that could also be on the table for authentication, or is that pretty much hampered by the potential advertiser monetization for that particular channel or just kind of tried to get a sense of Disney Channel and others that could follow along the same lines?

headline: Walt Disney Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2011
componenttextpreview: We think we'll have opportunities to authenticate a number of our channels, the deal that we cut that was obviously the big one and one of the first was with Time Warner just for ESPN. We've been pretty vocal about the fact that the multi-channel or basic
componenttext: We think we'll have opportunities to authenticate a number of our channels, the deal that we cut that was obviously the big one and one of the first was with Time Warner just for ESPN. We've been pretty vocal about the fact that the multi-channel or basic expanded basic cable service is of great value to the consumer, particularly when you consider substantially increased investment in original programming that's available in all those channels. So you're right now getting a lot more quality and a lot more choice, and we think it's a pretty good consumer proposition. If we can add to that authentication, which is giving the consumer the ability to watch that channel in more places as we did with ESPN so you can turn a laptop on in Los Angeles if you're a Time Warner customer or in New York and watch ESPN, that's a big deal. Because all you're doing is the value creating enhanced value with the package that's being offered and for the consumer and for the distributor. So we are extremely supportive of authentication, and believe that this is just the beginning of a trend that we'll be seeing, just not just for ESPN but for multiple Disney owned so-called cable television properties.

headline: Walt Disney Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2011

headline: Walt Disney Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2011
componenttextpreview: Bob, could you detail the Toy Story 3 unit sell through number in the quarter? And within that, could you just talk about the secular change, obviously, in DVD sell through as it applies to really all genres out there and has it forced you or Rich Ross or
componenttext: Bob, could you detail the Toy Story 3 unit sell through number in the quarter? And within that, could you just talk about the secular change, obviously, in DVD sell through as it applies to really all genres out there and has it forced you or Rich Ross or Rich Ross' team et cetera to rethink negative costs and to rethink how films are marketed?

headline: Walt Disney Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2011
componenttextpreview: I can give you more detail in terms of sell through rates or number of units that were sold in the quarter for Toy Story 3. The overall home video marketplace for the industry has softened, continues to soften. We've been relatively well-positioned becaus
componenttext: I can give you more detail in terms of sell through rates or number of units that were sold in the quarter for Toy Story 3. The overall home video marketplace for the industry has softened, continues to soften. We've been relatively well-positioned because of the strength of the brand, the nature of the title that we put out and as we've said a number of times, the fact that we tend to make movies that people want to own so their kids can watch them a multiple times. We also our librarying or managing our libraries very well so that when we bring certain product out, we create events by bringing them out and defy logic so to speak in terms of the marketplace. So Toy Story was a successful title internationally. Certainly the sell through rates, when you consider the conversion and the size of the box office substantially different than the marketplace we saw years back. Interestingly enough, what Toy Story 3 did was it increased sales of Toy Story 1 and 2, which we found very interesting. The library title that I thought was really interesting was we brought Beauty and the Beast back in Blu-ray in the fall, and that was extremely well-received. We bring these out as events and we package them very well in our stores and retail with a variety of different consumer products, and that's been a winning proposition. We've also seen a fair amount of success with some of our direct-the-video titles. And interestingly enough over the last three, four years, they've been fairly steady in terms of performance, and we have not seen the erosion of those kind of titles that we've seen with some of certainly the live-action the live action titles. In terms of the overall impact of home video to the Movie business, we've been steadily reducing the number of Movie titles that we make in a year. We, as you know, are talking about well under 10 Disney-branded titles a year that will include certainly a Pixar title, and hopefully a Disney animation title per year and add to that a couple of Marvel titles per year and then we'll be distributing the DreamWorks titles. We like the level that we're talking about in terms of total investment, and we're going to look as part of that mix to make big blockbusters that have big budgets Because not only we believe the work as movies but they work as franchises for the company and it's company wide or business wide events, Pirates is a great example of that. And we're also going to build into that mix relatively inexpensive titles, Disney-branded but much lower budget. I don't want to speak for the whole industry, but I think for our studio, and they know this well, it's extremely wise to take a very eyes-wide-open approach to the transfer seeing in the marketplace and we react accordingly in terms of expense. And then also react accordingly in terms of how the product is brought to marketplace in terms of pricing and windows and nature of the packages and the offering. And we'll get into that a lot more than next week.

headline: Walt Disney Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2011
componenttextpreview: Obviously, John, we've been talking a couple of quarters now about having a ratings supported by better programming on ABC. We've also been investing in ABC Family. And you all know, on the cable side, we're heavily investing in, XT, Disney Jr. and so on.
componenttext: Obviously, John, we've been talking a couple of quarters now about having a ratings supported by better programming on ABC. We've also been investing in ABC Family. And you all know, on the cable side, we're heavily investing in, XT, Disney Jr. and so on. I think we continue to want and create and own great programming for the ABC Network. It is for us a platform to create content that can be utilized broadly across the spectrum. It's the first window of distribution for great product, and we want to follow our principles of great creative product leading the way for the company. So we will continue to invest in that. You saw on our release on the flip side, margins have been greatly improved by being more prudent on the cost side relative to news and daytime, and we continue to work both sides of that. But make no bones about it, we want to have great creative products out there and we're investing behind it.

headline: Walt Disney Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2011
componenttextpreview: We have someone new in the role of prime time, Head of prime time for ABC, Paul Lee. And he and I talked a long time, he's in a job that I had many, many years ago. I advised them that in heading to the up front in The Middle of pilot season, that it's ab
componenttext: We have someone new in the role of prime time, Head of prime time for ABC, Paul Lee. And he and I talked a long time, he's in a job that I had many, many years ago. I advised them that in heading to the up front in The Middle of pilot season, that it's about making great shows, it's not about making a lot of them. The meaning and development it's not about volume it's about quality and that doesn't mean they looking to increase pricing or reduce pricing on what you make, but you ought to be making the right  thing sand if he sees product that he feels is mediocre then don't make it. There's been a trend at times in the business to fill slots and just to make a lot of pilots. I don't think that that's why particularly in the time it's really competitive for talent. It doesn't help when you water down the field. And I think he's being really disciplined it's very early and I like the product that he's developing and we'll get the chance to see what he's made of and we'll schedule together from there. It's important to make the right decisions and not just make a lot of product.
